;;我;;很容易被粗俗的语言分散注意力。多米尼克·卡明斯是否后悔在 WhatsApp 消息中称部长们为“无用的混蛋”、“白痴”和“混蛋”，或者将内阁办公室描述为“可怕的狗屎”？为 10 月 31 日的 covid-19 调查提供证据，;鲍里斯·约翰逊(Boris Johnson) 的前任首席助手;具有典型的刻薄态度。如果说有什么不同的话，那就是他“低估了”政府在应对新冠疫情时内部功能失调的程度。

;
;;
;

;许多国家已经完成了简短而尖锐的演习，以从大流行中吸取教训。英国庞大的调查将试图剖析国家几乎每个部分的运作情况。至少到 2026 年，证人都会受到讯问。律师将仔细研究大量文件，并试图以某种方式确定叙述的真实性。

;

;回顾过去，;英国的处理方式; 疫情似乎并不像以前那么严重。从粗略衡量超额死亡人数来看，该国排名接近中间位置，这在很大程度上得益于令人印象深刻的快速疫苗推出。但调查将探讨为什么英国在疫苗接种到来之前表现如此糟糕，调查政府在封锁、疗养院和公共卫生指导方面的决定。今年秋天的听证会重点关注唐宁街 10 号和内阁办公室，这将是最有趣的会议之一。他们头上盘旋着一个问题：是英国政府准备不足，还是当权者极其不适合这项工作？

;
;
;
;
;

;
;
;
;
;;
;

;例如，众所周知，该国的国家风险评估未能对一种新型病原体进行预测和规划，而且该州在调整应对流感大流行的计划方面进展缓慢。内阁办公室缺乏基本数据来追踪正在发生的事情。 2021 年，卡明斯向议会委员会表示，各部门对这场危机的责任极其混乱。本周他重申，国家应对紧急情况的核心部门反应极其缓慢。

;

;然而，现在出现在证人席上的大名鼎鼎的证人增强了人们的感觉，即混乱是由个人造成的。约翰逊作为一位不严肃、优柔寡断、无法把握细节的首相形象并不新鲜。不过，令人难忘的色彩正在被添加。在一封邮件中，约翰逊思考老年人是否应该接受自己的命运（同时展示了对“中位年龄”和“预期寿命”概念的粗略掌握）。正如一位前媒体顾问本周在证人席上所说的那样，新冠病毒“不适合他的技能”。 （约翰逊先生本人预计将于下个月露面。）

;

;至于卡明斯先生，他将自己定位为对系统感兴趣的说真话的特立独行者。但他似乎没有能力管理一个正常运转的办公室。有一次，他抱怨说，当他担任总理办公厅主任七个月时，10 号会议在基本层面上没有发挥作用。 11 月 1 日，时任内阁副部长海伦·麦克纳马拉 (Helen MacNamara) 描述了一种有毒、男子气概和性别歧视的环境。

;

;所有这些都给尚未提供证据的内阁秘书西蒙·凯斯提出了难题。这对里希·苏纳克来说也是个坏兆头，他也将在下个月接受调查。首相不仅将面临有关他担任总理期间的棘手问题。正是苏纳克先生在过去的一年里;■;

; Sat, 04 Nov 2023 09:27:02 +0800 A new gonorrhoea drug was developed by a non-profit foundation | Science & technologyhttps://www.economist.com/science-and-technology/2023/11/01/a-new-gonorrhea-drug-was-developed-by-a-non-profit-foundation ;
;< /div>;

;;G;;ONORRHoEA 是; ;一个;老毛病。 《利未记》提到了一种传染性疾病，涉及持续射精和勃起疼痛。仅仅 2500 年后，也就是 20 世纪中叶，抗生素的发现才让人们的生活得到缓解。

;
;;
;

;但也许不会持续很长时间。几十年来接触抗生素导致了 N.淋病杆菌（引起该疾病的细菌）产生耐药性。随着市场上几乎没有新的抗生素上市，这种细菌再次占据了上风。许多国家都有治疗失败的报告。现已被世界卫生组织指定为“优先”病原体。

;

;11月1日，新型抗生素佐利氟达星临床试验取得成功的消息令人欣喜。该药物抑制一种称为 II 型拓扑异构酶的酶，该酶对细菌繁殖至关重要。然而，比佐利氟达星如何发挥作用更有趣的是它是如何产生的。大多数药物是由私营公司开发的。 Zoliflodacin 是在美国政府和全球抗生素研究与开发伙伴关系 (;GARDP;) 的协助下创建的，该伙伴关系是一个非营利组织，由大型慈善机构 Wellcome Trust 和瑞士日内瓦州。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;;GARDP; 与 Innoviva Specialty Therapeutics 合作，Innoviva Specialty Therapeutics 是一家美国制药公司。该公司负责早期开发，并正在引导该药物在美国食品和药物管理局注册。美国国家过敏和传染病研究所指导其完成第二阶段试验，检查新药是否有效。 ;GARDP; 支持该药物通过后续更大规模的 3 期试验，这是药物批准使用之前的最后阶段。它的支持使得这些试验能够根据公共卫生目标进行定制，例如将女性、青少年和;艾滋病毒感染者;等高危患者纳入试验。 ;GARDP; 也在处理许可事宜，希望这将使佐利氟达星变得便宜且广泛使用。

;

;;GARDP; 发言人邓肯·格雷厄姆-罗 (Duncan Graham-Rowe) 表示这种伙伴关系可以增加新抗生素的供应。 （另一个非营利组织;CARB;-;X;也在做类似的工作。）近几十年来新药的缺乏主要反映了激励措施不力。为了延缓耐药性的产生，需要储备新的抗生素，直到真正需要它们为止。但搁置数年的药物在商业上没有吸引力。

;

;各国政府试图通过一些想法来解决这个问题，例如保证价格和即使不使用药物也每年支付费用。国营制药公司也已被讨论。要证明 ;GARDP; 已经找到了成功的秘诀，需要的不仅仅是唑利氟达星。但迹象是好的：它正在开发其他四种抗生素，其中一种用于复杂的尿路感染，而且更多的抗生素正在开发中。;■;

;;;;经过 5 个月;的反攻后，乌克兰仅以17公里。俄罗斯在东部巴克穆特周围战斗了十个月，“占领了一座六乘六公里的城镇”。乌克兰总司令瓦列里·扎卢日尼将军在本周接受《经济学人》采访时首次对这场战役进行了全面评估，他表示，战场让他回想起一个世纪前的伟大冲突。 “就像第一次世界大战一样，我们的技术水平已经达到了让我们陷入僵局的程度，”他说。将军的结论是，需要巨大的技术飞跃才能打破;iOS; ; ;Android;。;

;;

;您的浏览器不支持<音频>;元素。

;;
;
;
;
;;
;
;

;阅读我们最近对;乌克兰战争;

;
;

;反攻的过程破坏了西方国家希望乌克兰能够利用它来表明战争是无法获胜的，迫使俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京进行谈判。这也削弱了扎卢日内将军的假设，即他可以通过让俄罗斯军队流血来阻止俄罗斯。 “那是我的错误。俄罗斯已造成至少15万人死亡。在任何其他国家，这样的伤亡都会让战争停止。”但在俄罗斯则不然，那里的生活很便宜，普京的参考点是第一次和第二次世界大战，俄罗斯在这场战争中损失了数千万美元。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;乌克兰标准的军队应该能够快速移动它突破了俄罗斯防线，每天行驶 30 公里。 “如果你看看<小>;北约;的教科书和我们所做的数学计算，四个月的时间应该足够我们到达克里米亚，在克里米亚作战，从克里米亚返回并又进又出，”扎卢日尼将军讽刺地说。相反，他眼睁睁地看着自己的部队在通往东部巴赫穆特的道路上陷入雷区，他的西方提供的装备遭到俄罗斯大炮和无人机的轰炸。同样的情况也发生在南部进攻的主攻上，缺乏经验的旅立即陷入了麻烦。

;

;“首先我认为我们的指挥官出了问题，所以我更换了其中的一些指挥官。然后我想也许我们的士兵不适合任务，所以我调动了一些旅的士兵，”扎卢日尼将军说。当这些改变未能产生效果时，将军告诉他的工作人员翻出一本他学生时代看过的书。它的标题是“突破坚固的防线”。该书由苏联少将 PS 斯米尔诺夫于 1941 年出版，他分析了第一次世界大战的战役。 “还没读到一半，我就意识到这正是我们现在的处境，因为就像那时一样，我们今天的技术发展水平已经让我们和我们的敌人都陷入了昏迷。”

;
;<图>;;;;;;

;他说，这一论点得到了证实，因为他前往同样位于东部的阿夫迪夫卡的前线，俄罗斯最近通过派出两支军队，在几周内向前推进了数百米。 “我在那里的那天，在我们的监视器屏幕上，我们看到 140 台俄罗斯机器起火——在进入我们火炮射程的四小时内就被摧毁。”那些逃跑的人被“第一人称视角”无人机追赶，这些无人机携带爆炸物，操作员只需将其撞向敌人即可。当乌克兰军队试图推进时，同样的情况也会上演。扎卢日内将军描述了这样一个战场：现代传感器可以识别任何兵力集中，而现代精确武器可以摧毁它。 “一个简单的事实是，我们看到敌人所做的一切，他们也看到我们所做的一切。为了打破这种僵局，我们需要一些新的东西，比如中国人发明的火药，而我们仍然用它来互相残杀，”他说。

;

;然而，这一次，决定性因素将不再是单一的新发明，而是来自于所有现有技术解决方案的结合，他说。在 ;受扎卢日内将军为《经济学人》撰写的邀请;文章以及与该报分享的一篇文章，他敦促在无人机、电子战、反火炮能力和排雷设备，以及机器人的使用。

;

;西方盟友在向乌克兰提供最新技术和更强大的武器方面一直过于谨慎。美国总统乔·拜登在俄罗斯入侵之初就设定了目标：确保乌克兰不被击败，美国不被拖入与俄罗斯的对抗。这意味着西方提供的武器足以维持乌克兰的战争，但不足以让它获胜。扎卢日内将军并没有抱怨：“他们没有义务给我们任何东西，我们对我们所拥有的一切表示感谢，但我只是在陈述事实。”

;

;然而，通过抑制长期供应远程导弹系统和坦克，西方允许俄罗斯在 2022 年底北部哈尔科夫地区和南部赫尔松突然突破后重新集结并建立防御。一年，但他们今年才到达，”他说。同样，这位将军表示，明年推出的 ;F;-16 喷气式飞机现在的用处不大，部分原因是俄罗斯改进了其防空系统：;S; 的实验版本他警告说，-400 导弹系统可以到达第聂伯罗市以外。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;;

;扎卢日尼将军的评估发人深省：没有迹象表明技术突破即将到来，无论是无人机还是电子战领域。技术也有其局限性。即使在第一次世界大战中，1917年坦克的到来也不足以打破战场的僵局。德国在 1940 年 5 月发动闪电战，需要一套技术和十多年的战术创新。这意味着乌克兰陷入了一场长期战争——他承认俄罗斯在这场战争中具有优势。尽管如此，他坚称乌克兰别无选择，只能继续进攻以保持主动，即使每天只移动几米。

;

;将军认为，克里米亚仍然是普京最大的弱点。他的合法性在于2014年将其带回俄罗斯。过去几个月，乌克兰已将战争带入半岛，而半岛对于冲突的后勤仍然至关重要。 “它必须知道它是乌克兰的一部分，并且这场战争正在那里发生。” 10月30日，乌克兰首次使用美国提供的远程;ATACMS;导弹袭击了克里米亚。

;

;扎卢日内将军拼命阻止战争陷入战壕。 “消耗战的最大风险是它可能会持续数年并削弱乌克兰国家，”他说。在第一次世界大战中，在技术发挥作用之前，政治就进行了干预。四个帝国崩溃，俄罗斯爆发革命。

;

;普京预计乌克兰士气和西方支持都会崩溃。毫无疑问，扎卢日内将军认为，长期战争对俄罗斯有利，俄罗斯的人口是乌克兰的三倍，经济规模是乌克兰的十倍。 “说实话，这是一个封建国家，最便宜的资源就是人命。对我们来说……我们拥有的最昂贵的东西就是我们的员工，”他说。目前他的士兵已经足够了。但战争持续的时间越长，就越难以维持。 “我们需要寻找这个解决方案，我们需要找到这种火药，快速掌握它并利用它来迅速取得胜利。因为迟早我们会发现我们根本没有足够的人来战斗。” ;■;

; Sat, 04 Nov 2023 00:27:02 +0800 How the red beret became Africa’s most political hat | Middle East & Africahttps://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2023/11/02/how-the-red-beret-became-africas-most-political-hat ;

;;F;;法国革命者;戴着;胭脂红帽子;。唐纳德·特朗普的粉丝戴上;MAGA;棒球帽。对于非洲的年轻活动人士来说，红色贝雷帽是;必备;。南非煽动者朱利叶斯·马莱马 (Julius Malema) 表示，这顶帽子是“反抗和抵抗的革命象征”。

;
;;
;

;它是由马勒马先生和他的经济自由斗士的支持者们所喜爱的。民粹主义政党。波比·瓦恩 (Bobi Wine) 的追随者也佩戴它，波比·瓦恩是一名歌手兼反对派领袖，正试图推翻乌干达独裁总统。从加纳到津巴布韦的活动人士都戴着各种颜色的贝雷帽。

;

;发射一千顶帽子的头颅属于布基纳法索马克思主义总统托马斯·桑卡拉 (Thomas Sankara)，他于 1987 年被暗杀。看起来，他拒绝让自己的肖像挂在公共建筑上。但死后，他的形象在泛非左派中随处可见。他最初戴红色贝雷帽是因为他是一名军人（发动政变）。他说，他后来从切·格瓦拉那里获得了灵感，人们经常将他与他进行比较。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;<去年在布基纳法索领导政变的陆军上尉易卜拉欣·特拉奥雷模仿了桑卡拉的言论和头饰。但戴贝雷帽来营造激进氛围的一般都是平民活动人士。

;

;贝雷帽可以用来讽刺士兵和警察。尼日利亚活动人士奥莫耶莱·索沃雷 (Omoyele Sowore) 将他的橙色贝雷帽与以残暴闻名的警察所戴的黑色贝雷帽进行了对比。然而，这一上限也可能使一个人成为国家的目标。在乌干达，瓦恩先生头戴贝雷帽的追随者因穿着军装而被军事法庭定罪，这一罪行可能导致终身监禁。

;

;“贝雷帽唤起并承载着一种解放斗争的感觉，”加纳青年运动的召集人奥利弗·巴克-福尔马沃 (Oliver Barker-Vormawor) 说道，该运动希望推出自己的贝雷帽。对于许多放眼整个非洲大陆并看到民主、平等和尊严的承诺尚未兑现的非洲年轻人来说，贝雷帽无疑是一场尚未完成的革命的象征。然而，对于其他许多人来说，正如瓦恩先生所说，它可能只是比他年迈的对手约韦里·穆塞韦尼及其父母所戴的破旧太阳帽“更时尚”。;■;

;其他事情可能会更容易。两国解决方案代价高昂。甚至在战争之前，巴勒斯坦人就希望得到帮助来恢复加沙；现在账单会高得多。在 2000 年失败的戴维营峰会上，谈判代表讨论了一项 300 亿美元的基金，以补偿巴勒斯坦难民的财产损失。近年来，与以色列有联系的海湾州，例如沙特阿拉伯和阿拉伯联合酋长国（;阿联酋;），可能会更愿意赚钱，以表明他们没有放弃巴勒斯坦人。但是，

;

;最大的问题仍然不是解决方案的细节，而是谈判和实施解决方案的政治意愿。 ; Binyamin Netanyahu的;极右翼和宗教政客联盟。加沙战争结束后，这个联盟不太可能长期存在，内塔尼亚胡的反对者希望下一届政府能够更愿意与巴勒斯坦人进行谈判。一位以色列中间派议员表示：“我们吸取了教训，我们需要以一种好的方式与他们分开。” “是时候开始讨论了。”但是，从中心和左派的以色列政客们避免了十多年的公共问题。

;

;在巴勒斯坦方面，哈马斯一直渴望玩剧透。它在1990年代的首次自杀炸弹造成了奥斯陆的进程，及其在2000年至2005年的第二次起义（“起义”）中所做的大屠杀使以色列一代变成了一代以色列人反对妥协的想法。也许哈马斯在加沙战争后会消失，但另一个团体可以代替它。

;

;双方的普通百姓对两国解决方案失去了信心。无党派智囊团以色列民主研究所 2022 年 9 月的一项民意调查发现，只有 32% 的以色列犹太人支持这一计划，低于五年前的 47%。占人口五分之一的以色列阿拉伯人仍然认可了这个想法，尽管他们的支持也下降了，从2017年的87％下降到2022年的71％。

;支持在;巴勒斯坦;。巴勒斯坦政策和调查研究中心 2023 年 6 月的一项调查发现，只有 28% 的人仍然支持两国解决方案。十年前，大约有53％的人支持这个想法，尽管只有39％的人认为这是可行的。

;

;乐观主义者希望这些结果很糟糕：人们不太可能支持他们认为不可能的事情。有意义的和平进程可能会推动民意调查数字回升。 “我认为我们的人民不会拒绝结束占领的机会，”一位前巴勒斯坦部长表示。但是，最近几周的事件也可以使双方都反对妥协的想法。

;

;在以色列中，结束职业的一些最强大的支持者是负责运行它的人。哈马斯袭击事件发生后，很少有以色列人公开谈论两国解决方案或任何其他冲突解决方案。但国防部官员正在封闭的房间里讨论这个问题。这部分是因为战争的期望结束状态将塑造战争本身，因为内塔尼亚胡政府无力就以色列的长期战略进行严重辩论。

;
;
;
;
;
;VAT);, at the standard rate of 20%, and to remove a discount these schools receive on business rates—are still controversial. Given the party's yawning lead in the polls, they are also likely to become reality. As claims and counterclaims fly, three questions dominate. What is the case for making the tax changes? Would they materially affect private schools? And would they improve education in Britain?

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;On the rationale for the policy, Sir Keir Starmer, Labour's leader, has batted away claims that his party is contemptuous of aspirational parents; he has said he sees “no case” for trying to abolish fee-paying schools. Instead Labour's argument is that it is unjust to continue exempting from tax a service bought mostly by the rich.

;

;Research suggests that pupils in private schools learn more than they would if they studied in the state sector. Indeed, the fact that they get more and better qualifications is the biggest single reason they earn more than others in adulthood, according to academics at University College London (;UCL;) and Cambridge. (Chummy networks probably also help.) By the time they turn 25, privately educated Britons earn 17% more than workers from similar homes, according to research published in 2020. The pay premium widens by the age of 42, according to earlier research, to around 21% for women and 35% for men.

;
;;

;About three-quarters of children in Britain's private schools come from the richest 30% of families, according to another study by academics at ;UCL;. In contrast, only 2% of pupils come from the poorest third of families (see chart). Although private schools sometimes offer means-tested discounts aimed at drawing in poorer children, last year only about 7% of private-school pupils benefited. Of this small group, only about half received help amounting to 50% or more of total costs; only about one-quarter attended free.

;

;Critics say that the “partnerships” private schools boast of forming with state schools are underwhelming, sometimes involving little more than matches between their sports teams. It is also occasionally argued that private schools deprive government ones of wealthy and engaged parents. And according to Francis Green at ;UCL;, private schools educate less than 7% of pupils in England but employ around 14% of teachers.

;

;Private schools push back. They object in particular to Labour's claims that they are benefiting from “tax breaks”. Most education spending is exempted from consumption taxes, on the principle that encouraging adults to invest in youngsters' brains will benefit the country in the long run. Parents do not pay ;VAT; when they send toddlers to playgroups; undergraduates never pay ;VAT; on their tuition fees (even though degrees can greatly boost their incomes). Julie Robinson of the Independent Schools Council (;ISC;), a group representing more than half of Britain's 2,400 or so private schools, says it is rare for countries to tax school fees, and that if Britain were still in the ;EU; it would not be allowed.

;
;

;Fee or free

;

;Private schools also complain that debates about the sector focus on a handful of very toffee-nosed institutions, such as Eton, and on a subset of parents seeking a shortcut to Oxbridge. In fact, plenty of parents have turned to private schools in the hope that extra help might turn a struggling schoolchild into an average one. And lots of private schools offer specific educational or religious environments that are not available in the state sector. Lizzy Nesbitt, the principal of Emmanuel Christian School, a private primary with 60 pupils in Oxford that charges annual fees of about £6,500 ($7,900), thinks her school's families—about one-third of whom earn £40,000 or less—are probably not the kind that Labour is imagining it is targeting.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The second debate is what the effects of changing the tax rules would be. The; ISC; insists the impact of adding ;VAT; to school fees would be huge. A report it commissioned in 2018, when such a policy was last widely discussed, claimed that private-school enrolment could fall by 17-25% in the five years following; some 90,000-135,000 additional pupils would enter state schools. Competition for spots in the best government schools would inflate house prices in their catchment areas; adding lots of spots to the state system would cost money. Labour says it will raise £1.7bn from its plan; the ;ISC;'s study warned that the reform might raise little extra cash.

;

;There is good reason to think the consequences would be much less dramatic. The Institute for Fiscal Studies (;IFS;), a think-tank, argues that there is only a very weak relationship between the cost of private schooling and the number of parents who pay for it. Average private-school fees, now £15,200 a year, have jumped by 20% in real terms since 2010 and by 55% since 2003, for reasons unrelated to the government. Over that time the share of all children who are educated privately has barely budged. Private-school parents are increasingly concentrated in very high-earning professions such as finance, goes one explanation; fees are also more likely to be paid in part or in full by rich grandparents.

;

;The ;IFS;'s best guess is that adding ;VAT; to fees would cause private-school enrolment to fall by 3-7% (up to 40,000 kids) over several years. It thinks the policy would raise about £1.3bn-1.5bn for the government—equal to about 2% of the state-school budget. Unlike other analysts, it argues that parents who stop paying school fees will probably end up spending the money they save on other things, most of which would be taxed. So even if as many as 15% of pupils shifted, the change would still raise about £1bn.

;

;Again, however, the impact is likely to be unevenly distributed. About half of private schools have fewer than 290 pupils; a quarter have fewer than 155. Even modest swings in enrolment could hit these fairly hard. The largest and most elite schools may be less affected. Businesses that charge ;VAT; are exempt from paying the tax on their own “inputs”; the greatest beneficiaries would be schools that spend the most on things other than teachers' pay, including luxuries such as golf courses.

;

;The final question is what scale of improvements Labour can drive in the state sector with the extra tax receipts. So far it has promised to spend £350m hiring 6,500 more teachers, which would swell the state-school workforce by around 1%. It talks of spending a similar amount providing breakfast clubs in primary schools, which some evidence suggests can boost how much the littlest pupils learn.

;

;A vaguer list of uncosted aspirations contains nothing anyone could find offensive but may not drive big improvements. Labour has rejected the government's proposal that all pupils study maths until 18; its alternative idea, to keep improving maths teaching in the early primary years, seems both less ambitious and less responsive to what international data suggest are currently schools' biggest flaws.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;During the years of Conservative rule England's schools have drifted up international league tables. That has probably had less to do with funding—which has too often been miserly—than with unpopular reforms to curriculums and tests. Pushing up standards in the state sector has made it gradually harder for private-school pupils to win places on the most prestigious degree courses. That, as well as efforts by elite universities to increase their state-school intake, may be a bigger threat to fee-paying schools than any change in tax rules.

;

;Arguments, in other words, are being over-egged on all sides. Private schools will lose some pupils but fewer than they claim, especially among their core constituency of rich parents. Labour will draw a bit of cash from rich parents and please a lot of its voters, but the most-affected private schools and parents are likely to be smaller and less wealthy, respectively. The money raised will be useful at the margins but it will not fix the biggest issues in schools. The signals sent by this issue arouse passions; its actual importance is less great. ;■;

;
;

;;M;;urder on the; television, agony on the radio;互联网上的谎言和仇恨，还有你在意识到自己的错误之前点击的鼻烟视频。这个星球是一个沸腾的大锅，而你是其​​中一只自鸣得意的青蛙。 When the real world feels like a charnel house, why spend an evening and a chunk of cash watching bodies pile up on stage?

;

;And in “King Lear”, ;Shakespeare; piles them high. “That's but a trifle here,” a character says of another's demise during the final die-in.; But the play—and Sir Kenneth Branagh's ingenious new production in London—make a powerful case for subjecting yourself to ;tragic art;, even at a time of surround-sound horror.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;These days “King Lear” is performed less often than “Hamlet”, with its startlingly acute psychology, or “Othello” and ;“Macbeth”;, with their overtly modern themes of race, misogyny and the corrupting effects of power. Critics have frequently regarded “Lear” as a triumph of philosophical poetry but impractical as a play. There is just too much of it, and too much in it: too many ideas and emotions, too many stories and, above all, too much desolation and despair.

;

;The evil characters destroy one another, but they take the good down with them. Love kills; man is nothing but a “poor, bare, forked animal”. Throughout the 18th century this bleakness seemed so shocking, even immoral, that “Lear” was staged with a revised happy ending. Audiences still struggle with emotional overload. A decade ago, at another vaunted production in London, people sniggered when they were meant to weep.

;

;Sir Kenneth, a British ;actor and director;, stars in and directs the version that opened at the Wyndham's Theatre on October 31st. (It goes to the Shed in New York in 2024.) Part of his response to the play's scale is to cut lots of it. Running with no interval for ice-cream and gossip, this is two hours of neat tragedy—set, boldly, in Neolithic Britain. Wearing animal skins and wielding spears, the cast hulks around a stark set that recalls Stonehenge, their faces intermittently looming on the stones in un-Neolithic projections. Above them hangs an orb resembling both a planet and an eyeball, which sometimes seems to bleed.

;

;Here the power struggle that follows Lear's division of his kingdom is less a clash of armies than a scrap for a bauble in the mud. Yet the absence of pomp also makes the family drama at the story's heart seem movingly intimate and familiar. Captured by his foes, arms bound behind his back, Sir Kenneth's Lear uses his beard to dry the tears of his beloved daughter Cordelia (Jessica Revell). Soon he heaves her corpse onto the stage, howling in grief; this time, nobody laughed.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;They chuckled at other moments though, as Sir Kenneth judiciously keeps and hones the funny bits to help the philosophy go down. It is not just the humour of absurdist madness and slapstick torment that hovers between pathos and ridicule, often called the “comedy of the grotesque”. There is also the comedy of charismatic devilment and gullibility, of champion wordplay and some of Shakespeare's most colourful insults.

;

;As for the purpose of tragedy: Edgar (Doug Colling) implies one as he drags his blind and suicidal father Gloucester (Joseph Kloska) across ancient Britain. “Men must endure/Their going hence, even as their coming hither,” he preaches. “Ripeness is all.” Life, in other words, is an endurance test. It follows that, for viewers, tragic art is a kind of practice in grinning and bearing it.

;

;We have had quite enough practice in that, today's punters may think; and a homily on stoicism makes a priggish sort of moral. Edgar's conclusion, however, is not the play's. The rationale it offers for its spectacle of pain is more than a lesson in patience, more even than the sense of solidarity in suffering that acting as fine as Sir Kenneth's can provide.

;

;“King Lear” is full of audiences: characters who witness folly, misery or cruelty and must choose what to do about them. Some weigh their interests and join in. Some wring their hands. A few resist, such as the heroic servant who objects as Cornwall (a sinister Hughie O'Donnell) rips out Gloucester's eyes in a spasm of bloodlust and impunity.

;

;It is hard to imagine yourself as Lear, even one as denuded as Sir Kenneth's. But maybe you could, just about, be like the unheralded minor figures who opt to act instead of merely watching. “O, you are men of stones,” the king cries at the close, demanding greater compassion for injustice from the surviving characters—and from the audience, too. Don't just sit there, the play urges.做一点事。 ;■;
